instruction: What is the vision of the Computer Science and Engineering department at EWU?
response: The vision of the CSE department at EWU is to be internationally renowned in Computer Science and Engineering and to exalt excellence in education, research, industrial profession, and entrepreneurship for sustainable transformation of the society.

instruction: Can you explain the mission of EWU's CSE department?
response: The CSE department's mission includes: 1) Advancing knowledge and learning of evolving challenges in Computer Science and Engineering through quality education and research for societal development, 2) Sustaining an outstanding hub dedicated to excellence in education, research & development, and entrepreneurship while gaining international recognition, and 3) Enhancing student quality with advanced knowledge and skills to meet contemporary needs in education, research, leadership, and entrepreneurship.

instruction: What are the program educational objectives (PEOs) for the CSE program?
response: The CSE program at EWU has three educational objectives: 1) Graduates will establish themselves as leading computational professionals or entrepreneurs and continue learning to address evolving challenges, 2) Graduates will engage in lifelong knowledge pursuit and interdisciplinary learning for careers in industry, research, academia, leadership, or entrepreneurship, and 3) Graduates will contribute to sustainable development and societal well-being through ethical and responsible application of CSE principles and practices.

instruction: What skills and abilities should graduates of EWU's CSE program have?
response: Graduates are expected to: apply mathematics, natural sciences, and engineering fundamentals to solve complex CSE problems, design systems and processes considering societal and environmental impacts, conduct research-based investigations, apply modern engineering and IT tools, understand societal and ethical responsibilities, work effectively in teams, communicate complex technical information, and engage in lifelong learning.

instruction: How are program outcomes linked to educational objectives in EWU CSE?
response: Program outcomes describe specific skills and knowledge that students acquire, which map directly to the program educational objectives (PEOs). For example, outcomes related to applying engineering knowledge and problem-solving map to PEO1, research and analytical skills map to PEO2, and ethical, societal, and teamwork skills map to PEO3.

instruction: What kind of knowledge will I gain in the CSE program?
response: You will gain knowledge across several profiles: K1) theory-based natural sciences, K2) mathematics and computational theory for modeling and analysis, K3) engineering fundamentals, K4) specialized engineering knowledge, K5) design-support knowledge, K6) practical engineering skills, K7) understanding of societal, ethical, and sustainability issues, and K8) engagement with current research literature.

instruction: What types of engineering problems will I learn to solve in CSE at EWU?
response: You will tackle problems including: EP1) problems requiring in-depth engineering knowledge and first-principles analysis, EP2) wide-ranging or conflicting technical issues, EP3) abstract problems with no obvious solution, EP4) infrequently encountered issues, EP5) problems outside standard engineering codes, EP6) issues involving diverse stakeholders, and EP7) high-level problems with multiple sub-components.

instruction: What engineering activities will I participate in as a CSE student?
response: CSE students will engage in activities such as: EA1) managing diverse resources like people, money, and technology, EA2) solving significant technical or conflicting issues, EA3) creatively applying engineering principles, EA4) handling activities with unpredictable consequences, and EA5) applying principle-based approaches beyond prior experience.

instruction: How many total credits are required to complete the CSE program at EWU?
response: The total credit requirement for the CSE program is 140 credits. This includes compulsory language and general education (9), elective general education (9), natural sciences (11), mathematics and statistics (15), core computer science and engineering courses (62), core capstone project (6), major compulsory and elective CSE courses (20), and non-major elective CSE courses (8).

instruction: What are the core components of the CSE curriculum at EWU?
response: The core curriculum consists of computer science and engineering courses totaling 62 credits, a 6-credit capstone project, 20 credits of major compulsory and elective courses, and 8 credits of non-major elective CSE courses. In addition, students complete general education, natural sciences, and mathematics/statistics courses.

instruction: What kind of ethical training does EWU provide for CSE students?
response: CSE students at EWU are trained to apply ethical principles, commit to professional responsibilities, and consider societal, health, safety, legal, cultural, and environmental implications of engineering work, ensuring responsible and professional practice in all projects and problem-solving activities.

instruction: How does the CSE program at EWU prepare students for research?
response: The program emphasizes research-based investigation of complex problems using literature engagement, experimental design, data analysis, and synthesis to provide valid conclusions. Students gain skills in applying modern tools and techniques to analyze and model CSE challenges, preparing them for academic or industrial research careers.

instruction: Will I get teamwork experience in the CSE program?
response: Yes, students are expected to function effectively both as individuals and as members or leaders in diverse, multidisciplinary teams. This includes collaborative problem solving, communication, and project management skills essential for real-world engineering practice.

instruction: How does EWU's CSE program support lifelong learning?
response: The program instills preparation and ability for independent and continuous learning, ensuring graduates can adapt to technological changes and pursue knowledge beyond formal education, supporting careers in research, academia, industry, and entrepreneurship.

instruction: What is the relationship between knowledge profiles and program outcomes in CSE?
response: Knowledge profiles (K1-K8) define the theoretical and practical understanding students gain, which support achieving specific program outcomes. For instance, applying mathematics and engineering fundamentals (K1-K4) helps solve complex problems (PO1-PO3), while engagement with research (K8) supports investigative and analytical outcomes.

instruction: How can I use my math knowledge in CSE projects at EWU?
response: In the CSE program, your mathematics skills, including numerical analysis, statistics, and formal computer science concepts (K2), are applied to model, analyze, and solve complex computing problems. This helps in algorithms, data analysis, simulation, and predictive modeling.

instruction: What kind of research skills will I develop in the CSE program?
response: You will learn to conduct investigations of complex problems using research-based knowledge, design experiments, analyze and interpret data, synthesize information, and draw valid conclusions. This prepares you for academic research, industrial R&D, or independent projects.

instruction: Will I learn to design systems that consider societal and environmental impact?
response: Yes, the program teaches you to design solutions considering public health, safety, cultural, societal, and environmental factors. This ensures your projects are ethically responsible and sustainable in real-world contexts.

instruction: How does EWU prepare me to work in teams as a CSE student?
response: You’ll engage in diverse team-based activities, acting as a member or leader in multidisciplinary groups. This includes collaborative problem solving, project planning, and communication skills, which mirror professional engineering environments.

instruction: Can I pursue entrepreneurship after graduating from CSE at EWU?
response: Absolutely. The program’s educational objectives emphasize entrepreneurship. You’ll acquire the technical knowledge, design thinking, and leadership skills necessary to start your own tech venture or innovate within existing companies.

instruction: How does EWU CSE help me think critically and creatively?
response: Through challenging engineering problems (EP1–EP7) and activities (EA1–EA5), you’ll practice abstract thinking, originality in analysis, and creative use of principles to solve problems with no obvious solutions, preparing you for innovation in your career.

instruction: Will I be able to communicate technical information effectively?
response: Yes, one of the program outcomes focuses on effective communication. You’ll learn to write reports, design documentation, make presentations, and give and receive instructions clearly, which is essential for professional work and academic collaboration.

instruction: What kind of practical tools and technology will I use in CSE courses?
response: You’ll gain hands-on experience with modern engineering and IT tools for modeling, simulation, prediction, and problem-solving (K6). This prepares you for real-world computing tasks and professional engineering practice.

instruction: How will EWU CSE help me become a responsible engineer?
response: You’ll be trained to apply ethical principles, understand societal responsibilities, and evaluate the impact of your work on public safety, society, and the environment. This ensures you act professionally and responsibly in all engineering activities.

instruction: Are there opportunities to tackle complex real-world problems?
response: Yes, the curriculum exposes you to high-level engineering problems (EP7) involving multiple components or sub-problems, diverse stakeholders, and challenging contexts. You’ll learn to analyze, design, and implement solutions using first-principles approaches.

instruction: What courses focus on core computer science skills?
response: The CSE program includes 62 credits of core computer science and engineering courses. These cover fundamental and advanced topics, equipping you with essential programming, algorithmic, system design, and software engineering skills.

instruction: Can I explore interdisciplinary learning in CSE at EWU?
response: Yes, the program encourages lifelong learning and interdisciplinary engagement. You’ll integrate knowledge from mathematics, natural sciences, engineering fundamentals, and IT to solve complex problems and pursue academic or industrial careers.

instruction: How does EWU ensure I understand sustainability in engineering?
response: You’ll evaluate the societal and environmental impact of your solutions, consider sustainable practices, and incorporate ethical and safety standards, ensuring your engineering work contributes positively to society and the environment.

instruction: What kinds of capstone projects will I do in CSE?
response: The program includes a 6-credit core capstone project where you apply cumulative knowledge to design, implement, and analyze a substantial computing project. Projects often address real-world problems, involve teamwork, and require research and innovation.

instruction: Are there non-major electives in the CSE curriculum?
response: Yes, 8 credits are allocated for non-major elective CSE courses. These allow you to explore complementary skills and broaden your expertise beyond core computer science topics.

instruction: How are knowledge areas like K1 to K8 applied in daily coursework?
response: K1-K8 knowledge profiles guide your learning: K1-K4 underpin problem-solving and design, K5-K6 support practical and technological applications, K7 ensures ethical and societal considerations, and K8 involves research engagement. Together, they shape how you analyze, implement, and communicate solutions.

instruction: Will I get training in managing engineering projects?
response: Yes, one of the program outcomes focuses on understanding engineering management principles and economic decision-making. You’ll apply these skills in teamwork, project planning, and multidisciplinary projects, preparing you for leadership roles.

instruction: Do I get exposure to ethical dilemmas in computing?
response: Absolutely. The program emphasizes ethical responsibilities, ensuring you understand societal, legal, safety, and cultural issues in computing. You’ll learn to make informed, responsible decisions when facing ethical dilemmas in professional practice.

instruction: How does EWU prepare CSE students for lifelong learning?
response: The curriculum fosters independence and adaptability. You’ll learn how to engage with evolving technologies, research, and complex problems, ensuring you continue learning throughout your career in industry, academia, or entrepreneurship.

instruction: Can I apply this knowledge in real industry scenarios?
response: Yes, the program is designed to equip you with practical skills, modern tools, and analytical techniques to solve real-world computing problems, address stakeholder needs, and innovate responsibly in industrial, research, or entrepreneurial settings.

instruction: What are the compulsory courses for Intelligent Systems and Data Science?
response: The compulsory courses for the major 'Intelligent Systems and Data Science' are: Statistics for Data Science (CSE303), Artificial Intelligence (CSE366).

instruction: What is Statistics for Data Science (CSE303) about in the Intelligent Systems and Data Science major?
response: Statistics for Data Science (CSE303) is a compulsory course for the major 'Intelligent Systems and Data Science' with 4 credits. Prerequisites: STA102.

instruction: What is Artificial Intelligence (CSE366) about in the Intelligent Systems and Data Science major?
response: Artificial Intelligence (CSE366) is a compulsory course for the major 'Intelligent Systems and Data Science' with 4 credits. Prerequisites: CSE246.

instruction: Can you give me an overview of the first year CSE courses at EWU?
response: In the first year of CSE at EWU, students take foundational courses. In the 1st semester, there are Basic English (3 credits), Differential and Integral Calculus (3 credits), and Structured Programming (4.5 credits), totaling 10.5 credits. In the 2nd semester, students study Composition and Communication Skills (3 credits), Differential Equations and Special Functions (3 credits), Discrete Mathematics (3 credits), and Engineering Chemistry (4 credits), totaling 13 credits. The 3rd semester includes Engineering Physics-I (4 credits), Coordinate Geometry and Vector Analysis (3 credits), and Object Oriented Programming (4.5 credits), totaling 11.5 credits.

instruction: What courses are included in the second year of CSE?
response: In the 2nd year, students continue with core and general education courses. The 1st semester has Emergence of Bangladesh (3 credits), Statistics and Probability (3 credits), Computer-Aided Engineering Drawing (1 credit), and Electrical Circuits (4 credits), totaling 11 credits. The 2nd semester includes Elective General Education-I (3 credits), Linear Algebra and Complex Variables (3 credits), Data Structures (4 credits), and Electronic Circuits (4 credits), totaling 14 credits. The 3rd semester has Elective General Education-II (3 credits), Engineering Physics-II (3 credits), and Operating Systems (4 credits), totaling 10 credits.

instruction: Which courses do third-year CSE students take in the first semester?
response: In the 3rd year, 1st semester, CSE students take Elective General Education-III (3 credits), Algorithms (4.5 credits), and Database Systems (4.5 credits), totaling 12 credits.

instruction: Can you tell me about the third-year, second semester CSE courses?
response: In the 3rd year, 2nd semester, students study Digital Logic Design (4 credits), Information System Analysis and Design (4 credits), and Compulsory Major-I (4 credits), totaling 12 credits.

instruction: What courses are offered in the third-year, third semester?
response: In the 3rd year, 3rd semester, the courses are Computer Architecture (3 credits), Computer Networks (4 credits), and Compulsory Major-II (4 credits), totaling 11 credits.

instruction: How is the fourth year structured for CSE students at EWU?
response: The 4th year of CSE focuses on advanced electives and projects. In the 1st semester, students take Capstone Project-I (1 credit), Green Computing (3 credits), Elective Major-I (4 credits), and Elective Non-Major-I (4 credits), totaling 12 credits. The 2nd semester includes Capstone Project-II (2 credits), Cyber Security, Ethics and Law (3 credits), Elective Major-II (4 credits), and Elective Non-Major-II (4 credits), totaling 13 credits. The 3rd semester has Capstone Project-III (3 credits), IT Project Management and Entrepreneurship (3 credits), and Elective Major-III (4 credits), totaling 10 credits.

instruction: How many total credits does a CSE student take in the first semester of the first year?
response: In the 1st semester of the first year, a CSE student takes 10.5 credits: Basic English (3), Differential and Integral Calculus (3), and Structured Programming (4.5).

instruction: What is the total credit load for the second semester of the first year?
response: The total credit load in the 2nd semester of the first year is 13 credits, covering Composition and Communication Skills (3), Differential Equations and Special Functions (3), Discrete Mathematics (3), and Engineering Chemistry (4).

instruction: Are there general education electives in the CSE curriculum?
response: Yes, EWU's CSE curriculum includes general education electives. These appear in the 2nd year (Elective General Education-I and II), and in the 3rd year (Elective General Education-III), each worth 3 credits per semester.

instruction: Which semesters include capstone projects in the CSE program?
response: Capstone projects are included in the 4th year. Capstone Project-I is in the 1st semester (1 credit), Capstone Project-II in the 2nd semester (2 credits), and Capstone Project-III in the 3rd semester (3 credits).

instruction: How many credits are assigned to core programming courses in the first year?
response: In the first year, core programming courses include Structured Programming (4.5 credits) in the 1st semester and Object Oriented Programming (4.5 credits) in the 3rd semester, totaling 9 credits.

instruction: What is the credit load for major electives in the fourth year?
response: Major electives in the 4th year include Elective Major-I (4 credits) in the 1st semester, Elective Major-II (4 credits) in the 2nd semester, and Elective Major-III (4 credits) in the 3rd semester, totaling 12 credits across the year.

instruction: Which courses cover computer hardware and architecture topics?
response: Courses covering computer hardware and architecture include Electrical Circuits (4 credits) in 2nd year, Electronic Circuits (4 credits) in 2nd year, and Computer Architecture (3 credits) in 3rd year, providing foundational and advanced hardware knowledge.

instruction: When do students take Operating Systems in the CSE program?
response: Operating Systems is taken in the 2nd year, 3rd semester, with 4 credits.

instruction: Which semester includes Cyber Security, Ethics and Law?
response: Cyber Security, Ethics and Law is offered in the 4th year, 2nd semester, with 3 credits.

instruction: How many credits does a student take in the final semester?
response: In the 4th year, 3rd semester, students take a total of 10 credits: Capstone Project-III (3 credits), IT Project Management and Entrepreneurship (3 credits), and Elective Major-III (4 credits).

instruction: Which course should I take if I want to improve my English skills in the first year?
response: In the first year, you can take Basic English (ENG101, 3 credits) in the 1st semester and Composition and Communication Skills (ENG102, 3 credits) in the 2nd semester. These courses focus on reading, writing, and communication skills.

instruction: When do CSE students learn about Differential and Integral Calculus?
response: Differential and Integral Calculus (MAT101, 3 credits) is taught in the 1st semester of the 1st year as a foundation for advanced mathematics courses.

instruction: Is Discrete Mathematics a first-year course or second-year course?
response: Discrete Mathematics (CSE106, 3 credits) is taken in the 2nd semester of the 1st year.

instruction: Which semester covers Engineering Chemistry?
response: Engineering Chemistry (CHE109, 4 credits) is included in the 2nd semester of the first year.

instruction: What courses cover programming fundamentals in the first year?
response: Programming fundamentals are taught in Structured Programming (CSE103, 4.5 credits) in the 1st semester and Object Oriented Programming (CSE110, 4.5 credits) in the 3rd semester of the first year.

instruction: Which courses focus on physics in the CSE program?
response: Engineering Physics-I (PHY109, 4 credits) is in the 3rd semester of the 1st year, and Engineering Physics-II (PHY209, 3 credits) is in the 3rd semester of the 2nd year.

instruction: When do students study Linear Algebra and Complex Variables?
response: Linear Algebra and Complex Variables (MAT205, 3 credits) is taught in the 2nd semester of the 2nd year.

instruction: How many credits is the Data Structures course worth?
response: Data Structures (CSE207) is worth 4 credits and is taken in the 2nd semester of the 2nd year.

instruction: Which semester has the highest credit load in the second year?
response: The 2nd semester of the 2nd year has the highest credit load at 14 credits, including Elective General Education-I (3), Linear Algebra and Complex Variables (3), Data Structures (4), and Electronic Circuits (4).

instruction: Do students take any general education courses in the third year?
response: Yes, in the 3rd year, 1st semester students take Elective General Education-III (3 credits) to fulfill general education requirements.

instruction: Which courses teach algorithms and database concepts?
response: In the 3rd year, 1st semester, students take Algorithms (CSE246, 4.5 credits) and Database Systems (CSE302, 4.5 credits) to learn algorithmic and database concepts.

instruction: When do CSE students study digital logic design?
response: Digital Logic Design (CSE345, 4 credits) is taught in the 2nd semester of the 3rd year.

instruction: Which courses cover networking topics?
response: Computer Networks (CSE405, 4 credits) is taught in the 3rd semester of the 3rd year.

instruction: Which course teaches Operating Systems?
response: Operating Systems (CSE325, 4 credits) is offered in the 3rd semester of the 2nd year.

instruction: When is the first Capstone Project offered?
response: Capstone Project-I (CSE400, 1 credit) is offered in the 1st semester of the 4th year.

instruction: How many credits is Capstone Project-II?
response: Capstone Project-II (CSE400) is 2 credits and is taken in the 2nd semester of the 4th year.

instruction: Which semester includes IT Project Management and Entrepreneurship?
response: IT Project Management and Entrepreneurship (CSE495, 3 credits) is taken in the 3rd semester of the 4th year.

instruction: When do students take Green Computing?
response: Green Computing (CSE407, 3 credits) is offered in the 1st semester of the 4th year.

instruction: Which semesters include elective major courses?
response: Elective Major courses appear in the 4th year: Elective Major-I in 1st semester (4 credits), Elective Major-II in 2nd semester (4 credits), and Elective Major-III in 3rd semester (4 credits).

instruction: Do students take non-major electives?
response: Yes, in the 4th year, students take Elective Non-Major-I (4 credits) in the 1st semester and Elective Non-Major-II (4 credits) in the 2nd semester.

instruction: Which semester has the least number of total credits in the fourth year?
response: The 3rd semester of the 4th year has the least total credits at 10, including Capstone Project-III (3 credits), IT Project Management and Entrepreneurship (3 credits), and Elective Major-III (4 credits).

instruction: Which courses in the CSE curriculum focus on electronics?
response: Courses covering electronics include Electrical Circuits (CSE209, 4 credits) in 2nd year, 1st semester, and Electronic Circuits (CSE251, 4 credits) in 2nd year, 2nd semester.

instruction: When is Computer-Aided Engineering Drawing taught?
response: Computer-Aided Engineering Drawing (CSE200, 1 credit) is taught in the 1st semester of the 2nd year.

instruction: Which courses develop problem-solving skills using mathematics?
response: Courses like Differential and Integral Calculus (MAT101), Differential Equations and Special Functions (MAT102), Discrete Mathematics (CSE106), Linear Algebra and Complex Variables (MAT205), and Coordinate Geometry and Vector Analysis (MAT104) focus on mathematical problem-solving skills.

instruction: When do students take Statistics and Probability?
response: Statistics and Probability (STA102, 3 credits) is taken in the 1st semester of the 2nd year.

instruction: Which semester covers the emergence of Bangladesh?
response: Emergence of Bangladesh (GEN226, 3 credits) is taught in the 1st semester of the 2nd year.

instruction: Are there any courses that introduce cybersecurity topics?
response: Yes, Cyber Security, Ethics and Law (CSE487, 3 credits) is taught in the 2nd semester of the 4th year.

instruction: Which courses teach Object-Oriented Programming?
response: Object Oriented Programming (CSE110, 4.5 credits) is taught in the 3rd semester of the 1st year.

instruction: Do students take courses on computer networks before the third year?
response: No, Computer Networks (CSE405) is introduced in the 3rd semester of the 3rd year.

instruction: Which course teaches algorithms in detail?
response: Algorithms (CSE246, 4.5 credits) is taken in the 1st semester of the 3rd year.

instruction: When do students learn about Information System Analysis and Design?
response: Information System Analysis and Design (CSE347, 4 credits) is offered in the 2nd semester of the 3rd year.

instruction: How many courses are included in the first semester of the 2nd year?
response: The 1st semester of the 2nd year includes 4 courses: Emergence of Bangladesh, Statistics and Probability, Computer-Aided Engineering Drawing, and Electrical Circuits.

instruction: Which semester has the highest number of credits in the 4th year?
response: The 2nd semester of the 4th year has the highest credit load at 13, including Capstone Project-II (2), Cyber Security, Ethics and Law (3), Elective Major-II (4), and Elective Non-Major-II (4).

instruction: When is Computer Architecture taught in the CSE program?
response: Computer Architecture (CSE360, 3 credits) is taught in the 3rd semester of the 3rd year.

instruction: Which semester introduces database concepts?
response: Database Systems (CSE302, 4.5 credits) is taught in the 1st semester of the 3rd year.

instruction: Are there any courses related to entrepreneurship?
response: Yes, IT Project Management and Entrepreneurship (CSE495, 3 credits) is offered in the 3rd semester of the 4th year.

instruction: Which courses help in understanding electrical engineering basics?
response: Electrical Circuits (CSE209, 4 credits) and Electronic Circuits (CSE251, 4 credits) cover the basics of electrical engineering.

instruction: Do students take both physics and chemistry courses?
response: Yes, students take Engineering Chemistry (CHE109, 4 credits) in the 2nd semester of the 1st year, Engineering Physics-I (PHY109, 4 credits) in the 3rd semester of the 1st year, and Engineering Physics-II (PHY209, 3 credits) in the 3rd semester of the 2nd year.

instruction: How are major courses distributed across the program?
response: Major courses start in the 1st year with programming and math fundamentals, continue in the 2nd and 3rd years with Data Structures, Algorithms, Operating Systems, and Networks, and culminate in the 4th year with Elective Major courses and Capstone Projects.

instruction: Which courses teach statistical concepts?
response: Statistics and Probability (STA102, 3 credits) in the 1st semester of the 2nd year teaches statistical concepts relevant to CSE applications.

instruction: When is the last Capstone Project taken?
response: Capstone Project-III (CSE400, 3 credits) is taken in the 3rd semester of the 4th year.

instruction: Which courses prepare students for software development roles?
response: Courses like Structured Programming, Object Oriented Programming, Data Structures, Algorithms, Database Systems, and Information System Analysis and Design provide foundational and advanced knowledge for software development.

instruction: Which semesters have courses on electronic circuits?
response: Electrical Circuits (CSE209) is in 2nd year, 1st semester, and Electronic Circuits (CSE251) is in 2nd year, 2nd semester.

instruction: When do students study Coordinate Geometry and Vector Analysis?
response: Coordinate Geometry and Vector Analysis (MAT104, 3 credits) is taken in the 3rd semester of the 1st year.

instruction: Which courses provide foundational knowledge for algorithms?
response: Courses like Discrete Mathematics, Data Structures, and Linear Algebra and Complex Variables provide the mathematical and programming foundation for Algorithms (CSE246).

instruction: How many total credits are offered in the 3rd semester of the 2nd year?
response: The 3rd semester of the 2nd year has 10 credits, including Elective General Education-II (3), Engineering Physics-II (3), and Operating Systems (4).

instruction: Which courses cover ethics in computing?
response: Cyber Security, Ethics and Law (CSE487, 3 credits) in the 2nd semester of the 4th year covers ethical considerations in computing.

instruction: Are there any courses focused on project management in CSE?
response: Yes, IT Project Management and Entrepreneurship (CSE495, 3 credits) in the 3rd semester of the 4th year covers project management skills for IT professionals.

instruction: When is the first programming course offered in the curriculum?
response: The first programming course, Structured Programming (CSE103, 4.5 credits), is offered in the 1st semester of the 1st year.

instruction: Which courses introduce students to object-oriented concepts?
response: Object Oriented Programming (CSE110, 4.5 credits) in the 3rd semester of the 1st year introduces students to object-oriented concepts.
